description: This series examines the challenges companies face while supporting a bring your own device (BYOD) model. Each episode explores a potential mobile vulnerability and then explores methods to mitigate attacks exploiting that vulnerability. The series uses a hands-on approach actually demonstrating how each compromise works to help better inform systems administrators as to how these compromises occur.
descriptionMD: This series examines the challenges companies face while supporting a bring your own device (BYOD) model. Each episode explores a potential mobile vulnerability and then explores methods to mitigate attacks exploiting that vulnerability. The series uses a hands-on approach actually demonstrating how each compromise works to help better inform systems administrators as to how these compromises occur.
name: Mobile Security
subtitle: Mobile device risks and mitigation

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don discuss and demonstrate the exposure we have from unmanned mobile devices within a managed network.  Don describes some of the problems with them as well as the possible attacks.  He then demonstrates the way built security is working to protect itself on an Apple device by segregating applications and isolatingthe communication between application and the iOS and not allowing direct communication between applications.
episodes.title: Exposure from Unmanaged Mobile Device
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:01.664
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.664 --> 00:00:03.458
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.458 --> 00:00:03.977
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:03.977 --> 00:00:07.922
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.922 --> 00:00:11.010
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.010 --> 00:00:12.486
>> Welcome to ITProTV,

7
00:00:12.486 --> 00:00:17.660
you're watching emergent technology
security demonstrations.

8
00:00:17.660 --> 00:00:21.300
We're specifically gonna be diving
into the realm of taking look at

9
00:00:21.300 --> 00:00:24.200
exposures that we can get
from unmanaged devices.

10
00:00:24.200 --> 00:00:27.950
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and here to
help us out is gonna be Mr. Don Pezet.

11
00:00:27.950 --> 00:00:29.300
Don, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:29.300 --> 00:00:30.236
>> Thanks for having me, Ronnie.

13
00:00:30.236 --> 00:00:32.309
And yeah,
in this episode like Ronnie said,

14
00:00:32.309 --> 00:00:35.419
we're gonna take a look at what it
means to us, as administrators,

15
00:00:35.419 --> 00:00:38.880
if we have to deal with a network that
allows for unmanaged mobile devices.

16
00:00:38.880 --> 00:00:42.279
And, let's start right there with what
the heck is an unmanaged mobile device and

17
00:00:42.279 --> 00:00:44.110
we'll kinda get into the risk afterwards.

18
00:00:44.110 --> 00:00:48.695
We have this new movement going on
right now that's called the BYOD or

19
00:00:48.695 --> 00:00:50.920
bring your own device movement.

20
00:00:50.920 --> 00:00:54.504
In the past, like when I think about it,
when I got out of college,

21
00:00:54.504 --> 00:00:57.128
got my first IT job and
went to work for a company,

22
00:00:57.128 --> 00:01:00.510
they issued me a company laptop and
I had a company desktop.

23
00:01:00.510 --> 00:01:02.731
And so, when I was at work I
used the company desktop and

24
00:01:02.731 --> 00:01:05.050
when I was at home I
used the company laptop.

25
00:01:05.050 --> 00:01:08.290
And then, after a little while I
was issued a company cellphone.

26
00:01:08.290 --> 00:01:12.400
And, if I may work phone calls
I use my work cellphone.

27
00:01:12.400 --> 00:01:16.050
And, if I made personal calls,
I use my personal cellphone if I

28
00:01:16.050 --> 00:01:18.070
had even one back then I
don't think I even have one.

29
00:01:18.070 --> 00:01:20.980
So, that's how it was back in the day.

30
00:01:20.980 --> 00:01:22.530
Well the nice part about that is,

31
00:01:22.530 --> 00:01:26.860
because these were work devices, they were
completely controlled by the company.

32
00:01:26.860 --> 00:01:29.130
The company had total control and

33
00:01:29.130 --> 00:01:33.610
they could dictate what applications were
allowed to run, what permissions I had.

34
00:01:33.610 --> 00:01:35.650
Every aspect of that device, and

35
00:01:35.650 --> 00:01:37.959
that device's security was
dictated by the company.

36
00:01:39.220 --> 00:01:43.080
But, over time, right,
we had a lot of people wear it like me,

37
00:01:43.080 --> 00:01:46.260
I used a BlackBerry for ten years,
I used a BlackBerry and

38
00:01:46.260 --> 00:01:48.360
just thought it was the greatest thing.

39
00:01:48.360 --> 00:01:51.450
And then the iPhone came out and
the iPhone did so

40
00:01:51.450 --> 00:01:53.150
much more than the BlackBerry did.

41
00:01:53.150 --> 00:01:56.169
And then, the Android phones came out and
they did so

42
00:01:56.169 --> 00:01:59.404
much more and
I wanted to switch to one of those, right?

43
00:01:59.404 --> 00:02:00.820
>> [LAUGH]
>> And so, I went and bought my own.

44
00:02:00.820 --> 00:02:04.730
I did the first generation iPhone and
then the first generation Android phone.

45
00:02:04.730 --> 00:02:09.350
And now, I had these phones that
I like better than my work phone.

46
00:02:09.350 --> 00:02:11.850
And when I got to the office,
I didn't wanna use the work phone.

47
00:02:11.850 --> 00:02:13.030
I wanna use my phone.
>> [LAUGH]

48
00:02:13.030 --> 00:02:14.210
>> Or, maybe I had a laptop

49
00:02:14.210 --> 00:02:18.220
that was better than the one they issued
me for work and I wanted to use my own.

50
00:02:18.220 --> 00:02:22.850
But I couldn't because at the office,
they required us to use the work device,

51
00:02:22.850 --> 00:02:25.670
right, that ensured security.

52
00:02:25.670 --> 00:02:27.170
But that started to change.

53
00:02:27.170 --> 00:02:31.200
In the last five to ten years, companies
have started saying, wait a minute.

54
00:02:32.200 --> 00:02:35.700
If these people wanna buy their own
phones and they're willing to pay for

55
00:02:35.700 --> 00:02:37.460
it, we could save money.

56
00:02:37.460 --> 00:02:41.700
We could let them bring their
own device and use it for work.

57
00:02:41.700 --> 00:02:42.630
This is genius.

58
00:02:42.630 --> 00:02:44.195
Now we don't,
we don't have to do warranties,

59
00:02:44.195 --> 00:02:45.810
we don't have to do any of that stuff.

60
00:02:45.810 --> 00:02:48.050
They pay for it and they're willing
to do it, and they're happy to do it,

61
00:02:48.050 --> 00:02:51.202
'cause they get the device they
want.That's a, that's a win win, right?

62
00:02:51.202 --> 00:02:54.400
Company says, people get the device
they want, that's perfect.

63
00:02:54.400 --> 00:02:55.880
But it comes with a risk.

64
00:02:55.880 --> 00:02:59.360
And the risk is,
when somebody brings their own device,

65
00:02:59.360 --> 00:03:03.440
the company doesn't control it,
they can't control what apps are on it.

66
00:03:03.440 --> 00:03:08.196
They can't control whether it's secure or
not, whether it's being updated.

67
00:03:08.196 --> 00:03:10.070
They can't control any of that.

68
00:03:10.070 --> 00:03:12.720
And now, you might have people who yeah
they're bringing their own device,

69
00:03:12.720 --> 00:03:14.240
you save a little money.

70
00:03:14.240 --> 00:03:17.150
But, they compromise your network, right?

71
00:03:17.150 --> 00:03:22.000
We can really run some big risks by
allowing these unmanaged devices.

72
00:03:22.000 --> 00:03:26.080
And so, when that happens,
what are some of our biggest risks?

73
00:03:26.080 --> 00:03:29.950
Well, the biggest risk is leaking
your corporate data, right.

74
00:03:29.950 --> 00:03:31.892
And nowhere do we see
this more than email.

75
00:03:31.892 --> 00:03:36.331
All you have to do is turn on the news to
find out that celebrity acts or politician

76
00:03:36.331 --> 00:03:40.990
wise had their email compromised and
some of these read through all of it.

77
00:03:40.990 --> 00:03:45.785
That, if I'm checking my company
email on my personal phone, and

78
00:03:45.785 --> 00:03:49.810
my personal phone gets stolen or
gets lost, and

79
00:03:49.810 --> 00:03:55.560
it wasn't secured, somebody who finds that
phone, now has access to all of my email.

80
00:03:55.560 --> 00:03:57.380
And what can the company do about it?

81
00:03:57.380 --> 00:03:59.702
Nothing at that point,
the device is already gone, right?

82
00:03:59.702 --> 00:04:01.930
They lost their opportunity to control it.

83
00:04:01.930 --> 00:04:06.080
That should have been a managed device,
one that the company controlled, but

84
00:04:06.080 --> 00:04:07.140
it wasn't.

85
00:04:07.140 --> 00:04:10.770
And in super critical high secure
environments, it will be a device, right?

86
00:04:10.770 --> 00:04:13.890
Think about the president right,
when President Obama was elected,

87
00:04:13.890 --> 00:04:15.310
or President Trump,

88
00:04:15.310 --> 00:04:18.430
the news made a big deal out of both
of them with their cell phones.

89
00:04:18.430 --> 00:04:20.670
They had their personal cell
phones they really liked.

90
00:04:20.670 --> 00:04:22.900
And the government had to switch
them to one of the black phones.

91
00:04:22.900 --> 00:04:28.580
The secure phones, because just a regular
consumer grade phone is not gonna do for

92
00:04:28.580 --> 00:04:32.255
the President of the US so,
they had to switch to a secure phone.

93
00:04:32.255 --> 00:04:36.770
That is a reality, right, for
a high security environments.

94
00:04:36.770 --> 00:04:40.580
But if you're a medium size company,
or even a large business,

95
00:04:40.580 --> 00:04:43.320
you can save a lot of money by having
people bring their own devices,

96
00:04:43.320 --> 00:04:44.580
you just have to be smart about it.

97
00:04:44.580 --> 00:04:46.330
You have to secure them, protect them, and

98
00:04:46.330 --> 00:04:48.850
ensure those devices
are configured in a secure manner.

99
00:04:48.850 --> 00:04:52.070
And the best way to do
that is to manage them.

100
00:04:52.070 --> 00:04:54.750
Now in the next episode, we're gonna take
a look at actually using what's call

101
00:04:54.750 --> 00:04:58.280
mobile device management,
allowing us to manage those devices.

102
00:04:58.280 --> 00:05:02.030
But before we get in to that, let's talk
a little bit about the security features

103
00:05:02.030 --> 00:05:05.740
in the phones themselves that are supposed
to be helping us secure things.

104
00:05:05.740 --> 00:05:07.880
>> All right so, Don, help us out here.

105
00:05:07.880 --> 00:05:11.344
Now that we've got these types
of our own unmanaged devices,

106
00:05:11.344 --> 00:05:14.807
what are some of the attacks that
we're really looking out for

107
00:05:14.807 --> 00:05:17.486
when we're doing this
inside of our networks?

108
00:05:17.486 --> 00:05:20.928
>> Okay, so I mentioned not really
an attack, but a risk a minute ago.

109
00:05:20.928 --> 00:05:22.560
I said,
what if somebody loses their phone?

110
00:05:22.560 --> 00:05:26.680
I could find the phone and exploit it or
get the data out of that phone.

111
00:05:26.680 --> 00:05:29.130
Well, that's not really
a purposeful attack.

112
00:05:29.130 --> 00:05:30.330
That's a chance occurrence.

113
00:05:30.330 --> 00:05:32.390
I just happened to find a phone, great.

114
00:05:32.390 --> 00:05:36.500
But if somebody wants to target your
company and they know that you're using

115
00:05:36.500 --> 00:05:39.570
unmanaged devices, devices that have
been brought in by end users and

116
00:05:39.570 --> 00:05:44.250
they're managing themselves then, there's
a ton of attacks that are available.

117
00:05:44.250 --> 00:05:49.220
They can target them through a number of
things like Rouge App Stores and push

118
00:05:49.220 --> 00:05:53.440
Trojan Horses and malware and things like
that onto a phone to start tracking and

119
00:05:53.440 --> 00:05:55.500
leaking data out of that device.

120
00:05:55.500 --> 00:05:57.730
A remote exploit is probably
one of the biggest risks.

121
00:05:57.730 --> 00:06:00.224
We'll see in another
demonstration coming up.

122
00:06:00.224 --> 00:06:04.624
We've got jailbreaking end users
will sometimes intentionally

123
00:06:04.624 --> 00:06:09.090
make their phones less secure,
right, take an iOS device.

124
00:06:09.090 --> 00:06:15.080
When you buy an iPhone or an iPad, an iOS
device, it can only run applications

125
00:06:15.080 --> 00:06:19.600
pulled from the Apple App Store,
from the iTunes App Store, or whatever.

126
00:06:19.600 --> 00:06:24.430
Or, applications that have been digitally
signed by a trusted company, so

127
00:06:24.430 --> 00:06:27.310
a company can push their own applications
without going through the app store.

128
00:06:27.310 --> 00:06:31.071
But everything else has come to the app
store unless the user jailbreaks

129
00:06:31.071 --> 00:06:31.830
their phone.

130
00:06:31.830 --> 00:06:34.940
If they jailbreak it,
now they can install apps from anywhere.

131
00:06:34.940 --> 00:06:38.360
And maybe they wanna run things
like video game emulators.

132
00:06:38.360 --> 00:06:40.360
You can't run those on an iPhone normally.

133
00:06:40.360 --> 00:06:44.220
But you can pull them from these
alternative app stores if you jailbreak.

134
00:06:44.220 --> 00:06:47.980
And the risk there is, when you jailbreak,
you're weakening the security of the phone

135
00:06:47.980 --> 00:06:50.860
and that can be taken advantage of very,
very easily.

136
00:06:50.860 --> 00:06:53.630
That's something we just can't
allow in a corporate environment,

137
00:06:53.630 --> 00:06:54.910
weaken security too much.

138
00:06:56.090 --> 00:07:00.420
Surveillance, if an attacker gets
physical access to a phone, even for

139
00:07:00.420 --> 00:07:04.270
a moment ,there's a number of different
exploits they can apply to the phone,

140
00:07:04.270 --> 00:07:06.370
to set it up for
remote surveillance, right?

141
00:07:06.370 --> 00:07:11.142
And I'll show it in an episode later
on here, where we take a phone and

142
00:07:11.142 --> 00:07:15.686
we remotely exploit it,
we inject a malware into it via webpage.

143
00:07:15.686 --> 00:07:18.878
And once that's done, we can open up
a session, and do things like turn on

144
00:07:18.878 --> 00:07:22.520
the microphone, and listen to what's
going on on that phone, in that area.

145
00:07:22.520 --> 00:07:27.140
We can record what's on the camera,
we can send text messages from that phone.

146
00:07:27.140 --> 00:07:29.075
You can do all sorts of things, remotely.

147
00:07:29.075 --> 00:07:31.715
And from a surveillance perspective,
it's perfect

148
00:07:31.715 --> 00:07:35.455
because you've got a GPS on the phone,
so you can track where people are going.

149
00:07:35.455 --> 00:07:36.775
You've got a microphone,
you've got a camera.

150
00:07:36.775 --> 00:07:39.645
So now, you've got eyes and
ears on the person.

151
00:07:39.645 --> 00:07:44.085
You know exactly where they are,
all because that phone got exploited.

152
00:07:44.085 --> 00:07:45.177
We definitely don't want that.

153
00:07:45.177 --> 00:07:48.896
You might have security personnel that
monitor your physical building, and

154
00:07:48.896 --> 00:07:52.670
if they're bringing their own device and
those device is being compromised,

155
00:07:52.670 --> 00:07:56.272
now someone could determine where
the security guards or in a given time and

156
00:07:56.272 --> 00:07:58.929
use that as part of a physical
break in unto a facility.

157
00:07:58.929 --> 00:08:01.046
Those are things that
aren't just possible,

158
00:08:01.046 --> 00:08:03.551
these are things that have
already happened, right?

159
00:08:03.551 --> 00:08:05.730
There are documented cases
of these events occurring.

160
00:08:05.730 --> 00:08:08.308
So definitely something
we need to be aware of.

161
00:08:08.308 --> 00:08:10.682
And then lastly, data tampering.

162
00:08:10.682 --> 00:08:13.306
That if somebody has access
to your information,

163
00:08:13.306 --> 00:08:16.685
if they can get into the phone's data,
they can tamper with it.

164
00:08:16.685 --> 00:08:20.695
A Trojan horse is an example
where we modify an application to

165
00:08:20.695 --> 00:08:25.495
then phone home back to us and
send information, leak data, whatever,

166
00:08:25.495 --> 00:08:30.560
that we can tamper with the applications
on a phone or just our regular data.

167
00:08:30.560 --> 00:08:34.650
I might be having email records or other
files and folders stored on my phone.

168
00:08:34.650 --> 00:08:35.800
We can start to modify those records.

169
00:08:35.800 --> 00:08:39.320
These are all risks that we have when
a phone is not properly secured and

170
00:08:39.320 --> 00:08:42.243
even a heavily secured phone
can be risked to some of this,

171
00:08:42.243 --> 00:08:43.867
if it's not secured properly.

172
00:08:43.867 --> 00:08:45.643
We have to keep it patched and updated and

173
00:08:45.643 --> 00:08:48.946
all the things that we know we're
supposed to do but a lot of people don't.

174
00:08:48.946 --> 00:08:49.566
>> Now, Don,

175
00:08:49.566 --> 00:08:53.690
you make it sound fairly dangerous to
actually have an unmanaged device.

176
00:08:53.690 --> 00:08:57.500
But don't the devices themselves have
some form of security that we can use?

177
00:08:57.500 --> 00:08:58.450
>> They do, right?

178
00:08:58.450 --> 00:09:01.180
So phones actually do a lot
to secure themselves.

179
00:09:01.180 --> 00:09:05.157
But in a unmanaged device, right, so if I
go to the store and I buy my own phone,

180
00:09:05.157 --> 00:09:06.019
I now manage it.

181
00:09:06.019 --> 00:09:08.250
Not my company, I do.

182
00:09:08.250 --> 00:09:12.720
And as the end user, I can start to
turn off those protections, right?

183
00:09:12.720 --> 00:09:14.566
Think about a lock screen.

184
00:09:14.566 --> 00:09:19.978
If I wanna unlock my phone, most phones
have a method of doing this, right?

185
00:09:19.978 --> 00:09:22.276
And it could be as simple as
not having a lock screen.

186
00:09:22.276 --> 00:09:25.292
You push the power button and
you're phone is on and now you're in and

187
00:09:25.292 --> 00:09:26.184
off you go, right?

188
00:09:26.184 --> 00:09:28.912
Or maybe it's a number pad, right?

189
00:09:28.912 --> 00:09:33.653
So you turn the phone on and you've gotta
punch in a code to be able to get in or

190
00:09:33.653 --> 00:09:35.840
draw a pattern, to get in.

191
00:09:35.840 --> 00:09:38.450
Or maybe it's a finger print scanner,
a little more advanced, right?

192
00:09:38.450 --> 00:09:39.680
That's what I use on my phone.

193
00:09:39.680 --> 00:09:42.550
So if I turn my phone on I've gotta
use my finger print to unlock it.

194
00:09:42.550 --> 00:09:43.950
That really helps secure it.

195
00:09:43.950 --> 00:09:47.650
If I lose my phone, I leave it in a cab
somewhere, somebody else could find it but

196
00:09:47.650 --> 00:09:49.830
unless they have my code,
they're not gonna get at my data?

197
00:09:49.830 --> 00:09:54.980
So that's safe but if it's my phone,
I can turn that off.

198
00:09:54.980 --> 00:09:56.190
I can turn the finger print scanner off.

199
00:09:56.190 --> 00:10:01.070
I can turn the number code lock off,
pattern lock, whatever it is.

200
00:10:01.070 --> 00:10:03.190
And in fact,
they're usually off by default.

201
00:10:03.190 --> 00:10:06.130
So phones take steps,
they take precautions but

202
00:10:06.130 --> 00:10:08.330
a lot of times users don't
take advantage of them.

203
00:10:08.330 --> 00:10:10.520
And that's where managing
the devices comes in.

204
00:10:10.520 --> 00:10:12.820
Because a company can come
in with a manage policy and

205
00:10:12.820 --> 00:10:17.600
they can say look, your phone has to
have a lock screen, it's required.

206
00:10:17.600 --> 00:10:21.680
And it has to use either a finger print or

207
00:10:21.680 --> 00:10:25.270
a six digit PIN, not a four digit,
a six digit, right?

208
00:10:25.270 --> 00:10:29.525
You can dictate policies like that and
your phone has to be encrypted.

209
00:10:29.525 --> 00:10:34.200
And you know that almost every phone sold
today supports encrypting the file system.

210
00:10:34.200 --> 00:10:36.060
But most of them don't
do it out of the box.

211
00:10:36.060 --> 00:10:38.550
And the reason they don't is for
performance.

212
00:10:38.550 --> 00:10:41.410
They want the phone to run fast so
when the user buys it at the store,

213
00:10:41.410 --> 00:10:46.030
they see this snappy new fancy phone
that runs nice and fast but if they turn

214
00:10:46.030 --> 00:10:49.170
on encryption, it's more secured which
runs a little bit slower, right?

215
00:10:49.170 --> 00:10:50.920
Well for a regular end user,

216
00:10:50.920 --> 00:10:54.820
they might not care about encryption, they
might not care, they want it to go fast.

217
00:10:54.820 --> 00:10:56.380
Versus a company which'll say, hey,

218
00:10:56.380 --> 00:10:59.280
we'll gladly sacrifice
